Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Infrastructural Design Challenges in Municipal Planning Efforts Aimed at Maximizing Energy Efficiency

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
In 2007, half of the global population became concentrated in cities for the first time in human history. By 2050, nearly 90% of global population growth and 60% of aggregate energy consumption will occur in cities. Climate scientists suggest that efforts combat anthropogenic climate change will be won or lost in cities, especially through the large-scale transformation of urban transit networks. As municipal planners worldwide reckon with the ecological and public health hazards of mass automobility, a transition to decarbonized transit has emerged as a significant concern for municipal planners and engineers. This project, which trains a graduate student in methods of conducting empirically grounded scientific fieldwork, explores what factors contribute to the cultural and social efficacy and effectiveness of municipal planning efforts aimed at improving energy efficiency and optimizing mobility around urban infrastructures.

Through an ethnographic study of energy efficient infrastructure design, Rebecca Journey, under the supervision of Dr. Michael Fisch of the University of Chicago, will investigate the social and cultural factors that shape urban planning efforts. Tasked with retrofitting ever-sprawling cities with energy efficient transport infrastructure, urban planners are looking increasingly to Northern Europe for models. Within this context, the Danish capital and self-styled "eco-metropolis" of Copenhagen has surfaced as a prototype. At a municipal scale, this ambition is outlined in the Climate Plan, Copenhagen Municipality's long-range, comprehensive planning initiative to build the world's first carbon-neutral capital, and by extension, to shape a citizenry that might prove capable of mitigating climate concerns. To that end, this project will track a range of infrastructure design, development, and retrofit projects prescribed by the Climate Plan. Through participant-observation, multimedia documentation, and ethnographic interviews with city planners, architects, policymakers, and citizens, this research will investigate the sociocultural drivers and experiential dimensions of sustainable transport technology. For good reason, mobility studies have tended to focus on cars, trains and planes. Such studies have illuminated the inequitable distribution of resources in transit networks as well as the environmental and geopolitical hazards of fossil-fueled mobility. Yet in addition to rendering the harms of carbon-based transit apparent, mobility studies should attend to the modes by which alternatives become a thinkable and practical dimension of everyday life. This research takes up precisely this charge by enriching the social scientific study of infrastructure and mobility with the understudied regional and cultural perspective of Scandinavia.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Green design in Denmark today extends the moral promise of Danish Modern—to solve midcentury social problems through good design—to the late modern problem of climate change. Within the Danish urban planning world, this moral mandate assumes the form of the prototype: a scalable, provisional template from which a model of environmental stewardship may be locally adapted. This research considers the claims, affordances, and moral valences of the concept of prototype in a context in which climate change is framed as a problem of urban design. Based on an ethnographic study of green infrastructure design and experience in the self-styled “eco-metropolis” of Copenhagen, the project examines ongoing municipal efforts to build the world's first carbon-neutral capital, and by extension, to draft a prototype of an ethics for a post-fossil future. To that end the study tracks a range of green infrastructure design, development, and retrofit projects prescribed by the Climate Plan—Copenhagen Municipality's long-term, comprehensive urban planning initiative to achieve carbon-neutral status by 2025—from the ethnographic vantage of the bike path.

Contemporary mobility studies tend to focus on cars, trains and planes. Such studies have illuminated the structural violence of redlined resources in transit networks as well as the ecological and geopolitical hazards of petrocapitalism. Yet mobility studies should also attend to the ways in which low-impact alternatives become a thinkable and practical dimension of everyday life. This research takes up precisely this charge by expanding the emergent field of cycling studies with the understudied regional perspective of Scandinavia. 

Methodologically, the research will enrich an emergent literature in the anthropology of design by sketching a model for an ethnographic approach to design studies, one that considers the cultural dimensions of the urban built environment and the political imaginaries that cohere therein. A vast literature on Scandinavian Design exists, yet its scope is generally confined to the domains of architecture, furniture, and industrial design. This research considers Danish design outside of those realms by asking: What is good design when it overflows the living space? Applying an anthropological lens on design to infrastructure offers a fresh perspective on Danish design to material culture studies, as well as adds an ethnographic portrait to the modern art history of Scandinavia.

An ethnographic study of the ethics and aesthetics of green urbanism in Denmark intervenes amid interdisciplinary debates across the arts, humanities, and social sciences with crucial insights concerning urban futures at a critical time for theorizing the ecological agency of the municipal scale. In its anthropological approach to infrastructures as complex, mutliscalar ecologies critical to global ecological governance, this research will enable more complex applications of social scientific knowledge in urban policy development. The project moreover adds an ecological perspective to welfare state studies by developing a theory of welfare statecraft which posits environmental stewardship as a technology of social-democratic consensus. In so doing, the project pushes back on the cultural determinism implicit in the trope of Scandinavian exceptionalism which attributes the cohesion of the social-democratic welfare state to relative ethnic homogeneity.

Theoretically, this project contributes to a growing body of work known as the “anthropology of the good;” that is, the anthropological inquiry into the range of ways in which human beings strive for the good life; for instance, by resisting extractive infrastructures and building alternative futures. Writing in this vein, the dissertation based on this research will leverage a critique of the technocratic discourse of “sustainability” and propose an alternative conceptual rubric for reckoning with our common future on a warming planet. Simply put, the project invites American civil society to imagine low-impact alternatives for building that common future.
